column6: Although no specific mention of toxicity has been seen for this species, it belongs to a genus where many if not all the members have poisonous leaves and sometimes also the unripe fruits.
column8: A hybrid of garden origin, possibly S. guineense x S. villosum
column16: Solanum retroflexum is a ANNUAL. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs).  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It cannot grow in the shade. It prefers  moist soil.
column21: Fruit - raw or cooked. Not very appetizing raw, the flavour is improved by cooking[183]. We found the fruit to be much nicer than the rather similar S. nigrum guineense. Although smaller, it has a sweeter flavour[K]. Still not one of the most appetizing fruits to eat, though[K]. The fruit is about 1cm in diameter and is produced in small bunches[200, K].
column23: Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.None known
column27: An easily grown plant, it succeeds in most soils[1]. Prefers a fertile well-drained soil in a sunny position[200]. Often confused with the garden huckleberry, S. guineense, this species has smaller deep blue fruits[183]. Occasionally cultivated for its edible fruit, there are some named forms[200].
column28: Seed - sow spring in a greenhouse. When they are large enough to handle, prick the seedlings out into individual pots and plant them out after the last expected frosts.
